instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT is a power rail that powers the LED light in the screen of the device that allows you to see what is on the screen. When this is low or missing, the screen will be dim..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight (SOLVED)
threads.message:
I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> with no backlight. Tried multiple screens but no difference.

Took the board out and it seems that <TRANSISTOR>Q8400</TRANSISTOR> is getting its 12.9v PPVIN on pin 4 but the hate voltage is also 12.9v on pin 3 so isn't opening.

I can't seem to figure out why pin 3 isn't dropping.  The resistance between pin 4 and 3 is 80k so seems fine there.

Any help would be greatly appreciated

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight (SOLVED)
threads.message:
Any history available?
Do you get image for sure?

<SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> goes high?
Check it with LCD connected!

At least check for image on external monitor.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No backlight (SOLVED)
threads.message:
Hi 2informaticos, Thank you for the quick reply. I just sorted it thankfully.

It tested as low ohms on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S0_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> so I decided to inject 5v into that line and have a look on FLIR

The issue was with capacitor <CAPACITOR>C8470</CAPACITOR> shorting.
Replaced and now works fine.

I was having an off day obviously for not just doing this sooner.

Thanks again
